The Department of Defense (DOD), Washington Headquarters Services (WHS), has a requirement for Base Operations Support Services (BOS) Raven Rock Mountain Complex (RRMC).<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

BACKGROUND:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

This requirement is to consolidate various operational functions into all-encompassing facility support and operations service contract. The Government determined that it would be considerably more effective and efficient to consolidate these support services in a single award combination firm fixed price \\/ indefinite quantity contract. The single Contractor would provide an integrated management approach that orchestrates all system operations and support services with an integrated maintenance management system.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

The objective of this requirement is to supplement and support the Government workforce at RRMC by provide base operations and support services to maintain the mission.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

REQUIREMENTS:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

    \\\\n\\\\t
  • The contractor will be fully responsible for ensuring that the following services: Custodial Services, Dining Facility Operations, Logistics Support, and Transportation Services Support, are provided.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
  • The Contractor, through innovation, technology, or other means, shall perform the required BOS services at commercial standard frequencies for facilities of comparable size and usage. and Open \\/ Unrestricted\\\"}],\\\"contractTypes\\\":[{\\\"id\\\":1,\\\"title\\\":\\\"Firm Fixed Price\\\"}],\\\"createdDate\\\":\\\"2021-01-28T11:09:04.330\\\",\\\"description\\\":\\\"

    The Department of Homeland Security (DHS), United States Coast Guard (USCG) has a requirement for Non-Destructive Inspection (NDI) training.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

    BACKGROUND<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

    The United States Coast Guard (USCG) operates a fleet of approximately two-hundred (200) aircraft. Scheduled and emergent maintenance is performed on these aircraft by active-duty personnel at twenty-seven (27) different USCG Air Stations throughout the country. To ensure aircraft airworthiness and comply with Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) and USCG maintenance inspection procedures, Non-Destructive Inspection (NDI) methods are used, including Eddy Current, Fluorescent Penetrant, Magnetic Particle, and Ultrasonic. The USCG maintains approximately one hundred-twenty (120) fleet NDI inspectors, who receive certification as USCG Aviation Fleet NDI Level II Technician. These technicians possess the skills and knowledge to setup and calibrate NDI equipment, conduct tests, interpret, evaluate, and document results in accordance with USCG maintenance procedures. Traditionally, the USCG would train and certify USCG Aviation Fleet NDI Level II Technicians.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

    REQUIREMENTS<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

    The United States Coast Guard (USCG), Aviation Logistics Center (ALC), Engineering Services Division (ESD) has a requirement to obtain initial aircraft Non-Destructive Inspection (NDI) training for up to thirty (30) students per period of performance. For the purposes of this Statement of Work (SOW), the term “initial” indicates that the students have no previous NDI training or experience.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\",\\\"duration\\\":\\\"1 year(s) base plus 3 x 1 year(s) option(s) \\\",\\\"govEntity\\\":{\\\"id\\\":25281,\\\"title\\\":\\\"US COAST GUARD\\\"},\\\"id\\\":\\\"OPP201501\\\",\\\"iqOppId\\\":201501,\\\"oppValue\\\":500,\\\"primaryRequirement\\\":\\\"Education & Training\\\",\\\"procurement\\\":\\\"

    The General Services Administration (GSA), Greater Southwest Region has a continuing requirement for Appraisal and Appraisal-Related Consulting Services.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

    BACKGROUND<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

    The contracts will be used to support all program needs, including, but not limited to: portfolio management, real property acquisitions, exchanges and leases, and Federal outgrants (leases, easements, licenses, and permits of Federal property), reviews of third party appraisals reports, and consultations. These contracts will be utilized by GSA's Portfolio Management Division (PT) and are being established to provide timely, cost-effective, and professional appraisal, appraisal-related, and consulting services with optimum geographic coverage within Region 7.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      SUMMARY<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

      The Tennessee Department of General Services, on behalf of the Division of TennCare, may have a requirement for a TennCare Member Medical Appeals Independent Review Organization.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      BACKGROUND<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

      Statement of Procurement Purpose<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      The State intends to secure a contract with a URAC-accredited Independent Review Organization (IRO) (“Contractor”) for the provision of independent medical necessity reviews, and expert medical opinion testimony related to TennCare member benefit appeals, and, on a much smaller scale, related to TennCare member requests to change their managed care organization (“MCO”) assignment outside of the annual change period. If the Respondent intends to use subcontractors to accomplish any work required by this RFQ, then such subcontractor must also be a URAC-accredited Independent Review Organization.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      TennCare Member Benefit Appeal Process<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      When a TennCare member’s assigned managed care contractor (“MCC”) renders an adverse benefit determination, the member has the right to appeal the MCC-proposed adverse determination directly to the Division of TennCare. In other words, the member need not exhaust an MCC-level appeal process before requesting a “state fair hearing” (“fair hearing”). When TennCare receives such an appeal, TennCare engages its benefit appeal process. First, TennCare instructs the MCC to reconsider its proposed member-adverse decision. The MCC’s reconsideration decision must be written by a qualified decision maker who did not take part in the initial adverse determination for the benefit now under appeal. If, following reconsideration, the MCC upholds its initial adverse decision, Contractor performs an independent medical necessity review, and renders a written determination whether or not the benefit under appeal should have been approved in accordance with TennCare’s medical necessity rule and coverage criteria. If Contractor reverses the MCC’s proposed adverse benefit determination, TennCare instructs the MCC to authorize provision of the benefit under appeal. If Contractor upholds the MCC’s adverse benefit determination, the Contractor will be responsible for supplying expert opinion testimony in support of this benefit determination at the member’s fair hearing.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      Benefits Under Appeal and Requiring Contractor Medical Necessity Review<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      The Contractor will provide comprehensive medical, pharmacy, behavioral health, and dental expertise through a combination of full or part-time physicians, pharmacists, psychiatrists, orthodontists and dentists specializing in provision of the services under appeal. The following data is supplied in order to provide respondents with a better understanding of current TennCare benefit appeal volume and of the areas of clinical expertise required for the medical necessity reviewers.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

      For calendar year 2019, TennCare received 5771-member benefit appeals. Dental appeals comprised 51% of the overall volume, with pharmacy appeals comprising 26%, medical appeals comprising 19%, and behavioral health appeals comprising 3%.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

        \\\\n\\\\t
      • Dental: 51% (2921)\\\\n\\\\t
          \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
        • Orthodontia: 53% of dental (1538)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
        • Third Molar Extractions: 35% of dental (1014)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
        • Crowns, Injections, Outpatient, Oral Surgery: approx. 12%<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/ul>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • Pharmacy: 26% (1425 pharmacy appeals, 93 pharmacy reimbursement appeals)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • Medical: 19% (1093)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • Behavioral: 3% (175)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • Intellectual Disability: <1% (17)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • MCO Change: <1% (28)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
        • Non-Pharmacy R&B: <1% (10)<\\/li>\\\\n<\\/ul>\\\\n\\\\n

          Turnaround Times for Medical Necessity Reviews<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

          The turnaround time by which Contractor must complete the medical necessity review hinges on whether the appeal is designated for (1) expedited resolution or (2) standard resolution, and (3) on whether the member has been approved to receive continuation of benefits (COB) until the appeal’s resolution. In order for TennCare to meet applicable appeal resolution deadlines, the Contractor must complete the MNR within the following timeframes:<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

            \\\\n\\\\t
          1. 'Expedited’ MNRs must be completed and returned to TennCare within 24 hours (fewer than 1% of appeals involve expedited MNRs);<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
          2. ‘Standard’ MNRs must be completed within 11 calendar days (approximately 93% of appeals involve standard MNRs); and<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
          3. ‘COB-approved’ MNRs must be completed within 4 calendar days (during CY 2019, 6% of appeals met this designation).<\\/li>\\\\n<\\/ol>\\\\n\\\\n

            MCO Change Requests and Hardship Reviews<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

            When a member requests to change their assigned managed care organization (MCO) outside of the annual change period the change is only permitted if a member meets hardship. When a member alleges a hardship, the MCO will review to see if all of the hardship criteria are met. If the MCO determines that member does not meet hardship, Contractor will be asked to conduct an independent hardship review and render a determination on whether or not the member meets hardship in accordance with applicable TennCare or CoverKids rules related to MCO reassignment. If Contractor determines member meets all hardship criteria, TennCare will change the member’s MCO to the requested MCO. If Contractor determines the member does not meet all hardship criteria, the Contractor will be responsible for supplying expert opinion testimony at the member’s fair hearing. <\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

            REQUIREMENTS<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

            Medical Appeals<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

              \\\\n\\\\t
            1. The Contractor shall hire and maintain staff and management in accordance with the terms of this Contract. All Contractor staff shall be approved in writing by TennCare prior to performing any services required by this Contract.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
            2. The Contractor shall provide a proposed staffing plan within thirty (30) days following the start date of the Contract for review and approval by TennCare that shall include, at a minimum, the key staff identified below, and the corresponding job descriptions contained in Attachment C:\\\\n\\\\t
                \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
              1. A Tennessee licensed, medical director to assume operational responsibilities of the MRU and to provide medical leadership and expertise in conformity with applicable standards of medical necessity as determined by TennCare.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
              2. As part of the staffing plan, Contractor shall designate the key staff member or other employee who shall serve as the litigation hold officer for Contractor. The Contractor’s litigation hold officer shall be responsible for receiving notice of any litigation holds including document custodians who are Contractor key staff members, medical staff, employees or subcontractors, and for monitoring compliance with each litigation hold as instructed by TennCare.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/ol>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
              3. The Contractor shall provide staff as specified in A.10(f) and A.5. In conducting any medical necessity review of a member appeal under this Contract, the Contractor’s medical reviewer shall:\\\\n\\\\t
                  \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                1. Consult each member’s pertinent medical case history and medical records to ensure an individualized determination of medical necessity is provided consistent with TennCare or CoverKids rules and with TennCare\\/MCC guidelines and clinical criteria.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                2. Provide expert medical staff to testify on TennCare’s behalf at member’s medical appeal hearing as requested, concerning both medical reviews and appeals lodged by or on behalf of TennCare members concerning coverage and benefit determinations and member appeals. The Contractor shall analyze and identify trends associated to medical appeal data as requested by TennCare and shall identify any discrepancies and errors along with cost-effective solutions.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                3. Maintain current working knowledge on TennCare and CoverKids benefit coverage provisions and medical necessity requirements, and on the attendant TennCare\\/CoverKids\\/MCC clinical criteria and guidelines, including, but not limited to, the TennCare\\/CoverKids\\/PBM Preferred Drug List and Clinical Criterial, the DBM Provider Manual, and the MCC medical necessity guidelines.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                4. Shall be able to read and speak English fluently. If the Contractor fails to meet any requirement listed in this Section A.5. it may result in Liquidated Damages as described in Attachment A.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/ol>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                5. The Contractor shall provide TennCare with a curriculum vitae for each individual responsible for performing medical reviews under this Contract, including both Contractor-employed and subcontracted staff. The Contractor shall also provide TennCare with documentation verifying that all medical staff employed by the Contractor or employed as a sub-contractor are licensed to practice in their area of specialty within the United States. The Contractor shall provide documentation confirming that none of the medical staff are currently on the excluded status lists compiled by Medicare, Medicaid or the U.S. Office of Inspector General. The Contractor shall provide the documentation required by this Section A.6. upon execution of this Contract and on September 15 of each year of this Contract, including any amendments thereto. If the Contractor fails to provide the documentation required in this Section A.6. verifying that all medical staff employed by the Contractor or employed as a sub-contractor is licensed, the Contractor may be assessed Liquidated Damages as described in Attachment A.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                6. TennCare reserves the right, at its sole discretion, to restrict any person employed or subcontracted under this Contract from involvement in TennCare-related work. TennCare reserves the right, at its sole discretion, to request dismissal of Contractor staff and sub-contracted physician reviewers from this project based on performance deficiencies and\\/or lack of knowledge, skills, or demonstrated expertise necessary to perform contracted activities.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                7. The Contractor shall ensure that all Contractor-employed and sub-contracted physicians, pharmacy, orthodontia and dental reviewers are fully trained and maintain ongoing expertise on the applicable federal, TennCare and CoverKids rules and on the applicable TennCare\\/ CoverKids\\/MCC clinical criteria pertaining to the benefits under review including:\\\\n\\\\t
                    \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  1. applicable federal and state law and regulation<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  2. Tennessee’s Medicaid section 1115 demonstration (see Project No. 11-W-00151\\/4, approved by CMS on July 2, 2019)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  3. TennCare and CoverKids rules<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  4. MCO, PBM, and DBM contract requirements<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  5. MCO, PBM, and DBM policy and guidelines pertaining to TennCare, CoverKids, and medical necessity<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  6. All workflows, policies, and procedures pertaining to medical appeals processing.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                  7. A training plan that is approved by TennCare within ten (10) days of the execution of this Contract. The Contractor shall be responsible for providing training to any newly hired Contractor staff and sub-contracted reviewers prior to those individuals performing any medical or hardship reviews. The Contractor shall ensure that training for all current and newly hired Contractor staff and sub-contracted reviewers be consistent with the Contractor’s training plan.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/ol>\\\\n\\\\t<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                  8. The Contractor shall maintain staff hours from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. CST from Monday to Friday and shall maintain any additional hours required to fulfill the scope of services specified in this Contract.<\\/li>\\\\n<\\/ol>\\\\n\\\\n

                      The Department of Defense (DOD), Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA), has a requirement for Spectrum Operations Support Center (SOSC) Helpdesk.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                      BACKGROUND:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                      DISA's mission is to conduct DODIN operations for the joint warfighter to enable lethality across all warfighting domains in defense of our Nation.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                      DISA is a combat support agency of the Department of Defense (DoD). The agency is composed of more than 8,000 military and civilian employees. The agency provides, operates, and assures command and control and information-sharing capabilities and a globally accessible enterprise information infrastructure in direct support to joint warfighters, national level leaders, and other mission and coalition partners across the full spectrum of military operations.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                        The Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren Division (NSWCDD) is an engineering, software development, and systems test and integration center for RDT&E components of the US Navy. The purpose of this acquisition is to provide calibration and repair support services for NSWCDD, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Indian Head Explosive Ordnance Disposal Technology Division (NSWC IHEODTD), and alternate DOD locations.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                        This is a performance-based acquisition and is structured around the results to be achieved as opposed to the manner by which the work is to be performed. The quality and effectiveness of the services performed hereunder will be evaluated in accordance with the performance standards\\/acceptable quality and the evaluation methods described in Section E, Inspection and Acceptance, Quality Assurance Surveillance Plan.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                        REQUIREMENTS:<\\/b><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                        The contractor shall provide all personnel and necessary supervision required to operate an accredited Navy Repair\\/Calibration Facility at NSWCDD to include the following test and instrument calibration support services:<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          \\\\n\\\\t
                        • Calibration scheduling<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Calibration of Test, Measurement, & Diagnostic Equipment (TMDE), including onsite calibration<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Repair of TMDE (subject to prior review and approval by the COR)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Calibration Documentation<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Equipment shipping and receiving<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Pickup\\/delivery of test equipment<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Operation of equipment receipt and issue desk Procedures which establish and maintain a Navy certified and\\/or accredited Calibration Laboratory at NSWCDD<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Sending equipment out to be calibrated and ordering parts, standards, and materials required by the calibration laboratory (subject to prior review and approval by the COR)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Calibration and\\/or Measurement training for NSWCDD, NSWC IHEODTD or other Government activities supported by NSWCDD.<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Development of new Calibration\\/Measurement processes and procedures<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Develop and maintain measurement uncertainty processes and procedures<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Maintain NSWCDD, and NSWC IHEODTD calibration inventory database<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Test measurements and parts\\/material inspection<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                        • Produce and send out NSWCDD calibration recalls<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t

                          SUMMARY:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          \\\\n

                          The New York Office of General Services has a requirement for IT project consulting services. <\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          BACKGROUND:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          This Solicitation is issued by the New York State Office of General Services (OGS), a New York State (NYS) agency authorized by law to issue Centralized Contracts for use by NYS Agencies and other Authorized Users.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          This Solicitation will establish Centralized Contracts with Vendors to provide Project Based Information Technology Consulting Services to NYS Authorized Users on a statewide basis.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          The OGS Centralized Contracts will be established with vendors meeting specific requirements as detailed in this Solicitation. These OGS Centralized Contracts will establish a set of standardized terms and conditions, guidelines, processes, and templates for the development, distribution, and award of deliverable-based and fixed-price information technology projects, at the transactional level, through a Mini-Bid process. <\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          It is anticipated that the resultant OGS Centralized Contracts for Project Based Information Technology Consulting Services will improve the procurement process by reducing the amount of time and effort required by Authorized Users to engage consulting services for information technology (IT) projects.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          The OGS Centralized Contract sets forth a two-step process for each transaction.  The first step is the establishment of the centralized contract, through a non-competitive periodic recruitment process.  The second step will be competitive, based on the development of a specific project by an Authorized User in accordance with the contractual terms.  IT Project needs will be identified by an Authorized User, and documented in a Statement of Work (SOW). The project will then be distributed to Contractors based on specific Lot(s), via the Mini-Bid process.  An award will be based on best-value.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          The Mini-Bid award will result in an Authorized User Agreement for Project Based IT Consulting Services. Each Authorized User Agreement for Project Based IT Consulting Services will be governed first by the terms and conditions specified in the OGS Centralized Contract and second by terms and conditions added to the Authorized User Mini-Bid.  Any additional terms and conditions added to the Mini-Bid shall not conflict with the OGS Centralized Contract terms and conditions, and must provide additional benefit to the Authorized User.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          Services available under the resultant Contracts will be separated into three (3) distinct Lots.  Additional information about the minimum qualifications is set forth in Attachment 3 – Technical Submission.  A Vendor may respond to and receive an award for more than one (1) Lot.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          REQUIREMENTS:<\\/strong><\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          \\\\n
                          \\\\n

                          Project Based IT Consulting Services required by an Authorized User will be obtained via a Mini-Bid process under this Contract.  The Authorized User will issue a Mini-Bid with a SOW for the required Project Based IT Consulting Services.  An Mini-Bid may include, but will not be limited to, projects requiring: analysis, data classification, design, development, testing, quality assurance, security and associated training for IT based applications.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                          Additional examples of in-scope projects include, but are not limited to:<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                            \\\\n\\\\t
                          • Technical architecture advisory services<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Business Analysis for project development<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Proprietary software application development\\/customization, programming and integration<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Data Information Management  (including data migration, data conversion, data manipulation, data integration)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Project Management Project support services - including, but not limited to; project management, project quality assurance and control, and Independent Verification & Validation (IV&V)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Disaster Recovery\\/Business Continuity and Testing<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Quality Assurance<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Continuity of Operations Planning (COOP)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Data Categorization<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                          • Open-Source Software Implementation<\\/li>\\\\n<\\/ul>\\\\n\\\\n

                            Out-of-Scope Work<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                            There are service offerings expressly excluded from the scope of these contracts.  In many instances, such services and\\/or offerings are (or will be) covered by another OGS Centralized Contract.  Examples include:<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                              \\\\n\\\\t
                            • Staff augmentation services<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Time and material services<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Web hosting<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Automated network monitoring or any other service provided principally through an automated process<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Equipment maintenance<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Prepackaged training courses<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Managed services<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Acquisition of equipment (hardware)<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Acquisition of software, either Commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software or pre-existing software<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Cloud based or “As a Service” offerings, including but not limited to SaaS, IaaS, PaaS, and XaaS;  <\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Any offering that is a combination of equipment, hardware, software, cloud or “as a service offerings”<\\/li>\\\\n\\\\t
                            • Consulting or other installation work which is considered Public Works is excluded from purchase under the scope of this Solicitation.<\\/li>\\\\n<\\/ul>\\\\n\\\\n

                              Historically, the New York State Bureau of Public Works has maintained that installation, maintenance and repair of equipment attached to any wall, ceiling or floor or affixed by hard wiring or plumbing is public work. In contrast, installation of a piece of equipment which is portable or a “plug-in” free-standing unit would not be considered public work. Thus, this Solicitation does not authorize installation where the equipment becomes a permanent part of the building structure, or is otherwise incorporated into the fabric of the building (i.e. installation on a wall, ceiling or floor in a fixed location, or affixed by hard-wiring or plumbing). See Appendix B, Clause 10, Prevailing Wage Rates - Public Works and Building Services Contracts. For questions about whether a proposed work constitutes public work, please contact the New York State Department of Labor’s Bureau of Public Work District Office in a specific area.                               The Department of Justice, US Marshals Service has a requirement for home intrusion detection systems (Guam & Northern Mariana Islands).<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                              BACKGROUND AND REQUIREMENTS<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n

                              The USMS is responsible for roughly 10 residential accounts in GUAM AND NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. These private residences are located in both densely populated metropolitan areas as well as sparsely populated remote locations.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                              The Government envision a National Home Intrusion Detection Program in which the Program Management Contractor facilitates the United States Marshals Service (USMS) in project management as well as assisting in the coordination of maintenance, installation of home intrusion detection systems, and alarm monitoring. The USMS envision a single contract for Guam & Northern Mariana Islands. Home intrusion detection projects included the installation of an alarm panel, key pad, door\\/window sensors, motion sensor, and personal panic remote device, etc.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\\n

                              The USMS envisions an expansion of services that includes cameras and a mobile application for arming and disarming of security systems.<\\/p>\\\\n\\\",\\\"duration\\\":\\\"1 year(s) base plus 4 x 1 year(s) option(s) \\\",\\\"govEntity\\\":{\\\"id\\\":25398,\\\"title\\\":\\\"US MARSHALS SERVICE\\\"},\\\"id\\\":\\\"OPP198894\\\",\\\"iqOppId\\\":198894,\\\"oppValue\\\":0,\\\"primaryRequirement\\\":\\\"Electric & Electronic Components & Parts\\\",\\\"procurement\\\":\\\"

                              REQUIREMENTS<\\/h4>\\\\n\\\\n
                                \\\\n\\\\t
                              • Provide all services including:\\\\n\\\\t
                                  \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                                • Labor, materials, equipment, travel, and facilities to provide project management, exhibit planning, design, production, testing, fabrication, installation, and personnel training for exhibit elements, audiovisuals, interpretive signs and related media for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineer offices and agency partner offices within the St. Louis District and other locations\\\\n\\\\t\\\\t
                                    \\\\n\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t
